Palantir Technologies (PLTR) is riding theAIwave like no other in the software market . Traditional valuation metrics barely scratch the surface of what’s really going on . The company is dominating not just the enterprise space but the government sector too . With a price tag that essentially prices in perfection, there is no room for execution mistakes .  Palantir is a can’t-miss AI disruptor that deserves a premium valuation and a bullish rating . The company's Remaining Performance Obligations (RPO) shows the future contracted revenue locked into multi-year agreements . As of Q1 2025, RPO reported total RPO of $1.9 billion—almost half of the mid-term consensus forecast for annual revenue of $3.9 .  Palantir’s multi-year commitments offer a stable foundation that smooths out top-line swings and supports steady growth . The company's model isn’t pure SaaS but includes deep, customized services through platforms like Apollo and Gotham .  Palantir has built a unique competitive moat by combining advanced data analytics software with tailored services . This blend is tough for typical SaaS competitors to match, particularly in sensitive sectors like defense, intelligence, and critical infrastructure . The market has strong confidence in the company's ability to consistently convert this backlog into recognized revenue and sustain healthy billings growth .  Palantir not only exceeds the Rule of 40 but delivers a rare combo of fast growth and strong margins . Wedbush analyst Dan Ives sees the company as a “generational opportunity” ready to capitalize on the massive AI revolution . $2 trillion in software spending is expected over the next three years .  Palantir is still in its early stage, centered on disruptive potential and future growth . Among 18 analysts covering PLTR over the past three months, only three recommend buying, 11 remain neutral, and the other four suggest selling .  Palantir is positioned at the heart of a technological revolution, like AI, and is executing at a high level across both commercial and government verticals . With a growing backlog, strong margins, and a competitive moat that's only deepening, there’s little sign that the company's momentum is slowing anytime soon .

Nvidia director Mark Stevens sold more than 1 million shares this week, bringing in nearly $150 million . Analysts have noted that Stevens's disposals represent the largest individual trade outside of Chief Executive Officer Jensen Huang's planned sales . Revenue rose to $44.1 billion in the fiscal first quarter, up 69 percent from a year earlier .  Stevens's sales came from shares held by Third Millennium Trust, of which he and his wife serve as trustees . His net worth stands at $9.8 billion, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index . Other insiders have also put shares on the block .  Investors will watch for potential signs of slowing enterprise AI spending as trade policies evolve . Seawell adopted a plan in March to sell roughly 1.1 million shares . Upcoming catalysts include Nvidia's mid-year developer conference and any new commentary on AI chip supply constraints in China .

Nvidia has been the poster child for AI, but the stock has been volatile of late . Concerns about how AI models will evolve and whether they will need the latest and greatest chips sent some investors to the sidelines . Nvidia has delivered two successive quarters of high-double-digit revenue growth .  Nvidia's original claim to fame is developing the graphics processing units that generate lifelike images in video games . The company established a beachhead in AI as early as 2013, giving Nvidia more than a decade-long head start on the competition . After developing processors focused on machine learning, Nvidia quickly became the gold standard .  Nvidia generated record revenue of $44.1 billion, which surged 69% year over year . For its fiscal 2026 second quarter, Nvidia is guiding for record revenue . Thebuildout of data centersto meet the growing demand of AI continues, which bodes well for Nvidia .  Nvidia stock is selling for roughly 33 times forward earnings (as of this writing), which is an attractive valuation for a company that's expected to grow its profits by 50% in the coming quarter . Despite the rapid run over the past two years, it's still early days for the adoption of generative AI .  Given Nvidia's market-leading position, deeply entrenched technology, the magnitude of the opportunity, and its attractive valuation, I would argue it isn't too late to buy Nvidia stock . Nvidia’s Q1 results landed like a bombshell last week, shattering expectations with $44.1 billion in revenue, marking a 69% surge year-over-year . Even with a $4.5 billion hit from U.S. export restrictions on its China-bound H20 chips, the company didn’t waver, posting numbers that still left Wall Street stunned . And yet, NVDA stock lingers near last year's levels, even as profits soar .  NVIDIA’s vision of AI as critical infrastructure (like roads or power grids) does not exist in the realm of hype but is instead more like a blueprint for the future . With data center revenue making up 89% of Q1 revenue, NVIDIA's grip on AI's plumbing is only getting stronger .  Gaming revenue hit a record $3.8 billion, up 42% year-over-year thanks to the GeForce RTX 50 series . Networking is another unsung hero, with Q1 revenue soaring 64% to $5 billion . NVIDIA’s Spectrum-X Ethernet solutions are becoming the go-to for data centers handling massive AI workloads .  NVIDIA delivered a $2.5 billion sales loss in China in Q1 . The fact that growth still smashed expectations despite this setback made NVIDIA’s Q1 feel like a masterclass in navigating adversity . Without the H2O hit, adjusted gross margins would have reached 71.3%, proving the core business remains a profit juggernaut .  NVIDIA features a Strong Buy consensus rating, with 36 analysts currently bullish, four neutral, and just one bearish . At 34x this fiscal year’s expected EPS, I view the stock as quite attractively priced . Wall Street remains extremely bullish on NVDA stock .  NVIDIA isn’t just part of the tech revolution; it’s leading it, setting the standard for the entire industry . Investors dragging their feet risk missing out on what could be a once-in-a-generation opportunity to ride a true market giant to new heights .

NVIDIA’s increasing value, rise in first-quarter revenues, growing AI data center spending, demand for its latest chip and GPU, and potential growth in automotive revenues should encourage stakeholders to stay invested in NVDA stock . NVIDIA stands to benefit from the AI revolution in autonomous robots and self-driving cars .  NVIDIA has a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold) for now . The company is developing a ground-up redesign of data centers to an 800 V HVDC power architecture . Navitas, a $350 million or somarket company, was named in the announcement .  Navitas' stock went up 150% the day of the blogs, May 21, before retreating . But then the following week, Navitas disclosed it had exhausted its $50 million equity at-the-market sales facility, and that it had filed for a new $50M facility .  Last month's cash raise will bolster Navitas' balance sheet, giving it more time to build out its platform in anticipation of the 2027 Kyber rollout . Huawei Technologies has emerged as NVIDIA Corporation’s most high-profile rival in the race to power artificial intelligence development in China . But according to a report from The Information, the Chinese tech giant is struggling to gain traction with major domestic customers despite rising interest in homegrown solutions . ByteDance,Alibaba, andTencent Holdings Ltd(F:NNND) ADR (OTC:TCEHY) have yet to place significant orders for Huawei's Ascend chips .  Firms such as ByteDance and Alibaba have voiced concerns over performance shortcomings with Huawei’s hardware, as well as fear of violating U.S. trade laws . Transitioning from Nvidia to Huawei would also involve a high switching cost .  Huawei’s new AI compute system, CloudMatrix 384, attempts to compensate for individual chip performance by linking as many as 384 Ascend processors together . But the system faces technical roadblocks, including high power consumption and lack of native support for FP8, a low-precision number format essential to cutting-edge AI training . A recent U.S. Department of Commerce warning puts companies using Huawei's advanced AI chips at risk of criminal and administrative penalties .  Pressure tightens on both sides of the Pacific as pressure tightens . Tesla stock tumbles amid Trump criticism . Huawei struggles to break Nvidia’s AI chip grip in China .

General Motors is making significant strides in revolutionizing its manufacturing processes through a new partnership with chipmaker Nvidia . The collaboration aims to harness the power of artificial intelligence to enhance automation, cut costs and improve efficiency across GM’s factories . The automaker is using Nvidia Omniversewith Cosmos to create digital twins of its assembly lines .  The partnership extends to training robotics platforms for operations such as material handling, transport and precision welding . GM has developed systems that can identify potential issues in manufacturing, such as leaks in battery packs, allowing for quick repairs and supporting quality control .  Michigan, home to GM’s headquarters, accounts for nearly 28,000 robots . By 2015, the Detroit-Warren-Dearborn area had 15,115 industrial robots in place, or 8.5 per 1,000 workers . This high concentration of automation has contributed to a dramatic shift in GM's workforce composition over decades .  GM has implemented systems to inspect welds and paint coats, identifying irregularities and anomalies that might affect vehicle quality . This technology not only improves product quality but also enhances workplace safety by automating potentially hazardous tasks .  GM has pushed the start date at its Orion Assembly plant from 2024 to late 2025 . The company cites the need to “align its capital investments with electric vehicle demand and implement vehicle engineering improvements to boost profitability” Despite production delays, GM maintains ambitious plans .  GM’s transformation from “automaker to platform innovator” suggests a continuing shift toward higher-skilled, technology-focused employment . The Nvidia partnership positions GM to remain competitive in an increasingly technology-driven automotive landscape . “It's not about automating everything or building more vehicles faster — our winning formula is driven by a combination of flexible manufacturing, advanced technology, and a talented workforce”  GM plans to build next-generation vehicles on Nvidia DRIVE AGX, based on the Nvidia Blackwell architecture . This technology will deliver up to 1,000 trillion operations per second of high-performance compute . GM has maintained its position as the U.S. sales leader for three consecutive years through 2024 .  Kraft Heinz confirms $3B investment in U.S. manufacturing facilities . Kraft to invest $16B to expand semiconductor manufacturing and advanced packaging capabilities in New York and Vermont . GF’s investment is a response to the explosive growth in artificial intelligence .  Rolls-Royce to invest $24 million in US manufacturing . Investments could add 3,500 employees to the Lunchables producer’s workforce . New 250,000ft2 Logistics Operations Centre adjacent to existing manufacturing facility in Mankato, Minnesota .

ABB is a $100 billion Zurich-based industrial company that specializes in electrification and automation . ABB's products and services help manufacturers and governments achieve greater efficiency, energy management, and sustainability .  ABB's four business segments are approaching a combined $35 billion in sales this year at modest 6-7% growth . The company announced that it will launch a process to propose to its Annual General Meeting in 2026 to decide on a 100% spin-off of its Robotics division .  In 2015, ABB introduced YuMi, the world's first truly collaborative robot, capable of working safely alongside human beings . In 2020, the company introduced the "ABB Way" operating model, decentralizing the company . The company’s 20-odd divisions assumed the highest operating level, with full accountability .  ABB was formed from the merger of ASEA of Sweden and BBC of Switzerland in 1988 . The new company, headquartered in Zurich, had annual revenues of $17 billion and 160,000 employees at the time . Now they have over 18,500 staff at 40+ manufacturing and assembly locations, from the northeast, across the southeast and Midwest .  ABB claims that their Process Automation segment -- providing software, advanced services, and analytics to help customers create their own "safe and smart operations" -- is #2 in the market globally . ABB is steered from Houston, Texas .  Dozens of robotics startups are using NVIDIA tools to build the future of physical AI . Some of them will, if they make the cut, plan an IPO in the coming years .  NVIDIA's "IPO" could be less than a year away . NVIDIA CEO Jensen says humanoid robots will be the next multi-trillion-dollar industry .  American Eagle Outfitters is a Pittsburgh-based specialty casual apparel retailer . The number of malls in the US has dropped precipitously over the past few decades from more than 2,000 in the 1980s to roughly 700 today . AEO Direct is American Eagle’s online retailing channel .  AEO shares are showing troubling relative price action versus the S&P 500 Index . Year-to-date, shares are down nearly 40%, while the S-P 500 is flat . Wall Street analysts see negative EPS growth this year and AEO’s EPS to plunge by 52% next year! Nvidia is still the best-positioned chipmaker to benefit from ongoing enthusiasm around artificial intelligence, analysts at Bank of America say . Last week, Nvidia unveiled quarterly sales that topped expectations thanks to customers stocking up on its AI chips prior to the implementation of new U.S. restrictions on exports of cutting-edge processors to China .  China is now "fully de-risked" for Nvidia, analysts at BofA say . U.S. President Donald Trump's decision to lift a so-called AI diffusion rule that would have limited the global flows of American AI chips also opens access to opportunities in other countries .  The BofA analysts maintained their "buy" rating of Nvidia’s stock, which has risen by 2.6% so far this year . The strategists also named the firm as a "top pick" in the semiconductor sector . On Wednesday, Nvidia shares closed at $141.92 .

Nvidia's growth will propel it to the $5 trillion market cap spot first . The company's growth would be reaccelerating if it weren't for U.S. export restrictions . Nvidia's impressive rise can be tied to one trend: artificial intelligence .  Nvidia is at the top of the GPU world, and most estimates point toward it having roughly a 90% market share . Few companies achieve that level of dominance, and no other company has ever been as dominant in a trend as important and quickly growing as AI .  On April 9, the Trump administration established new rules that prevented Nvidia from selling H20 chips designed to meet export restrictions to China . This chip accounted for $4.6 billion of sales in Q1, which ended April 27 . Nvidia missed out on $2.5 billion in additional sales . The company expects about $8 billion in sales to be lost during the second quarter .  Growth is accelerating despite Nvidia's massive size if the H20 sales are added back in for a proper comparison . Wall Street currently projects Nvidia will grow its revenue by just 26% next year, but that is an underprojection . Even if it does match Wall Street's expectations, it will generate around $250 billion in revenue . US Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick said the Trump administration has been reworking agreements forged with semiconductor makers under the 2022 Chips Act . Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., a recipient of $6.6 billion in Chips Act grants, is adding $100 billion to a previous $65 billion pledge, he said .  Commerce secretary Lutnick spoke to a Senate Appropriations Committee . He suggested the administration may not follow through on some of the planned awards . Trump has urged Congress to repeal the 2022 Chips and Science Act that was a centerpiece of Biden’s domestic agenda .  Lutnick defended artificial intelligence deals with the United Arab Emirates unveiled last month during President Donald Trump’s trip to the Middle East . He said the accords were crafted to spur complementary levels of spending in the US . The path for those AI agreements in the Gulf was opened by a decision to revoke a regulation that had drawn strenuous objections .  Tensions over US efforts to rein in China's tech ambitions have deepened the conflict over trade . The US has moved to pressure allies against adopting Huawei Technologies Co.’s new Ascend chip . Commerce Department said last month that it was issuing guidance to warn the public .  Lutnick: China lacks capability to produce high volumes of sophisticated semiconductors . US export controls have limited China’s technological progress, he said . He estimated that China could probably produce about 200,000 advanced chips, like the kind used to train AI services or run smartphones . Microsoft first became the world's biggest company based on market cap in September 1998 . It stayed No. 1 for less than 18 months before being dethroned . Nvidia is in the best position to knock Microsoft off its perch with its market cap already topping $3.3 trillion .  Nvidia is poised to be the biggest beneficiary of several artificial intelligence (AI) trends, notably including the rapid adoption of AI agents that can reason . The restrictions on AI chip exports to China will hurt its growth to some extent . I don't think this headwind will keep Nvidia from becoming much larger over the next decade .  The big question hovering over Apple is: What's the next big breakthrough product for the company? I think smart glasses just might be the much-anticipated next huge hit for Apple . Rumors are circulating that the company plans to launch its first AI-enhanced glasses as early as late 2026 .  Amazon Web Services (AWS) will be able to hold on to its leadership in the cloud services market more strongly than I anticipated in the past . Without OpenAI's ChatGPT, I don't believe Microsoft would claim the largest market cap today . Another reason why I'm more optimistic about Amazon now is that it might be able launch smart glasses that become nearly as must-have as the iPhone years ago .  Amazon must grow significantly faster than Microsoft over the next 10 years for its market cap to become larger . Its AI initiatives are impressive, including the development of its own AI chips . Amazon is also expanding into new businesses, with the recent launch of its Project Kuiper satellites . Artificial intelligence (AI) stocks scored major gains over the past two years . Many companies selling products and services to power AI platforms and companies developing AI have seen both revenue and their share prices soar . Analysts predict that today's $300 billion market could surpass $2 trillion early next decade .  AI stocks have declined in recent weeks due to general concerns about economic growth . Investors have worried that higher prices on goods could lift costs for companies -- and prompt their customers to spend less . But indexes and stocks have recovered some of their losses amid positive news .  Nvidia's $53 billion in cash means it has the financial resources to support growth and handle challenges . I'm confident about Nvidia's ability to stand out this year thanks to messages from President Trump .  Nvidia has reported solid growth through the first quarter and high demand for something that could spur the next wave of revenue growth . The company's new Blackwell architecture was constructed with inferencing needs in mind -- so this should drive considerable growth for Nvidia in the quarters to come .  The U.S. has barred sales of its H20 chip, designed to meet earlier export guidelines, and that resulted in a $4.5 billion charge for the company in the recent quarter . Nvidia has spoken openly about how restricting sales of AI chips to China would hurt its potential for dominance in the industry . Still, even with that risk present, Nvidia stock could soar this year for the reasons I've mentioned above .  Nvidia is well positioned to soar over the long run . This bargain valuation could increase appetite for the stock, especially for investors who aim to hold on for the long term . As of the end of March, a mix of four well-known AI hardware and applications companies made up roughly 30% of Coatue Management's invested assets . The deadline for institutional investors overseeing at least $100 million in assets to file Form 13F with the Securities and Exchange is May 15 .  Coatue Management's Philippe Laffont ended March with $22.7 billion in assets under management . He leans heavily into growth stocks and companies riding the latest technological waves, such as the artificial intelligence (AI) revolution .  In four of the last five quarters, social media titan Meta Platforms has been billionaire Philippe Laffont's top holding . Coatue's more than 3.75-million-share stake equated to almost $2.2 billion in market value at the end of March .  Meta Platforms also has the luxury of an enviable treasure chest . Its cash, cash equivalents, and marketable securities collectively topped $70 billion at the end of March . Amazon has been a top-four holding for Coatue Management since the start of 2024 .  Amazon Web Services (AWS) is pacing $117 billion in annual run-rate revenue . AWS entered 2025 accounting for a 33% share of global cloud infrastructure service spending . Amazon's other high-growth ancillary segments are playing key roles in its growth .  The third largest holding in Philippe Laffont's fund for a second consecutive quarter is world-leading chip fabrication companyTaiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing . TSMC is in the process of increasing its CoWoS capacity from around 35,000 units per month in 2024 to 135,000 wafers per month by 2026 .  Laffont's sizable wager on Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing might also have to do with it building advanced-chip production facilities in the U.S. President Trump's threat of imposing tariffs on imports, including the possibility of tariffs, is more of a moot point with TSMC investing in America . The fourth AI stock that accounts for about 30% of Coatue Management's $22.7 billion in invested assets is Microsoft .  Microsoft is aggressively deploying generative AI and LLM tools in its cloud infrastructure service platform . Microsoft's legacy operations aren't slouches, either . Even though the growth heyday for Windows and Office is long gone, Microsoft's software still dominates .  Meta Platforms ended March with $79.6 billion in cash, cash equivalents, and short-term investments . The company generated $37 billion in net cash from operations in just three months . Nvidia, with a market value of $3.444 trillion, topped software giant Microsoft . This happened a week after Nvidia's report of double-digit revenue growth and strong demand for its artificial intelligence chips .  In January, Nvidia's market value surpassed those of Microsoft and smartphone giantApple . Concerns about technology spending weighed heavily on Nvidia shares in recent months . Now, though, two elements clearly are driving this rebound in the AI giant .  Nvidia reported strong demand for its latest release, the Blackwell architecture and chip, and noted that customers are rushing to the company for inferencing power . Nvidia's chips -- graphics processing units (GPUs) -- fuel this process that allows large language models to think through problems and generate answers .  One potential risk to Nvidia's share price performance is the situation concerning the export of AI chips to China . U.S. restrictions prevent Nvidia from selling its H20 chip -- one that it designed specifically for the Chinese market -- to that country . Nvidia may once again remain neck and neck with Microsoft and Apple when it comes to market cap . Hewlett Packard Enterprise appears to have stabilized its key server business . Execs said they have tightened up the economics around server deal pricing and are holding managers more accountable for performance . Margins in the business still tanked to 5.9% from 11% a year ago .  HPE announced several months ago that it would slash 3,000 jobs, equating to 5% of its workforce . The company expects to save about $350 million from the layoffs . In July, the company is heading to trial against the DOJ for its blocked $14 billion deal to acquire Cisco rival Juniper Networks .  Elliott's playbook often shakes up a company's board to unlock shareholder value . HPE has $11.7 billion in cash, equating to an outsized 50% of its market cap .
